section_id: ## 3. Lemma B: Exponential Contraction of Structural Variance

hints.label: lem-structural-variance-contraction
hints.title: Exponential Contraction of Structural Variance
hints.content:
1007: :label: lem-structural-variance-contraction
1008: 
1009: Let $\mu_t$ denote the empirical measure of a single realization of the Fragile Gas at time $t$, and let $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ be the quasi-stationary distribution.
1010: 
1011: Then the structural variance contracts exponentially in expectation:
1012: 
1013: $$
1014: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t} \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_0, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] + \frac{C_{\text{struct}}}{\lambda_{\text{struct}}}(1 - e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t})
1015: 
1016: $$
1017: 
1018: where:
1019: - $\lambda_{\text{struct}} = \min(\kappa_W/\tau, \kappa_{\text{kin}})$ is the exponential convergence rate
1020: - $\kappa_W > 0$ is the cloning operator Wasserstein contraction rate from {prf:ref}`thm-main-contraction-full`
1021: - $\kappa_{\text{kin}} > 0$ is the kinetic operator contraction rate from {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main`
1022: - $C_{\text{struct}} = C_W + C_{\text{kin}}\tau^2$ combines noise constants from both operators
1023: - $\tau$ is the time step size
hints.section: ## 3. Lemma B: Exponential Contraction of Structural Variance
hints.raw_directive:
1004: **Mathematical Foundation:** This lemma uses the Wasserstein contraction results established in the framework. The cloning operator ({prf:ref}`thm-main-contraction-full` from [04_wasserstein_contraction](04_wasserstein_contraction)) and the kinetic operator ({prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main` from [06_convergence](06_convergence)) each provide contraction of the Wasserstein distance **in expectation** after one step of the dynamics.
1005: 
1006: :::{prf:lemma} Exponential Contraction of Structural Variance
1007: :label: lem-structural-variance-contraction
1008: 
1009: Let $\mu_t$ denote the empirical measure of a single realization of the Fragile Gas at time $t$, and let $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ be the quasi-stationary distribution.
1010: 
1011: Then the structural variance contracts exponentially in expectation:
1012: 
1013: $$
1014: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t} \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_0, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] + \frac{C_{\text{struct}}}{\lambda_{\text{struct}}}(1 - e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t})
1015: 
1016: $$
1017: 
1018: where:
1019: - $\lambda_{\text{struct}} = \min(\kappa_W/\tau, \kappa_{\text{kin}})$ is the exponential convergence rate
1020: - $\kappa_W > 0$ is the cloning operator Wasserstein contraction rate from {prf:ref}`thm-main-contraction-full`
1021: - $\kappa_{\text{kin}} > 0$ is the kinetic operator contraction rate from {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main`
1022: - $C_{\text{struct}} = C_W + C_{\text{kin}}\tau^2$ combines noise constants from both operators
1023: - $\tau$ is the time step size

hints.label: proof-lem-structural-variance-contraction
hints.content:
1031: :label: proof-lem-structural-variance-contraction
1032: 
1033: The proof uses direct application of the Wasserstein contraction results from the framework, establishing convergence in expectation.
1034: 
1035: **Step 1: Expected Wasserstein Contraction from Cloning Operator**
1036: 
1037: From Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-main-contraction-full` in [04_wasserstein_contraction](04_wasserstein_contraction), the cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ satisfies:
1038: 
1039: $$
1040: \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_1), \Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_2))] \leq (1 - \kappa_W) W_2^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) + C_W
1041: 
1042: $$
1043: 
1044: where:
1045: - $\kappa_W > 0$ is the N-uniform contraction constant from the cluster-level analysis
1046: - $C_W = 4d\delta^2$ is the noise constant from Gaussian cloning perturbations
1047: - The expectation is taken over the randomness in the cloning operator (Gaussian perturbations and random pairing decisions)
1048: 
1049: **Note on convergence type:** This establishes convergence of the **expected** Wasserstein distance, which is the appropriate notion for stochastic processes. The inequality bounds how the second moment $\mathbb{E}[W_2^2]$ evolves, not the distance between individual random realizations.
1050: 
1051: **Step 2: Wasserstein Contraction from Kinetic Operator**
1052: 
1053: From Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main` in [06_convergence](06_convergence), the composed operator's Foster-Lyapunov function includes a Wasserstein component $V_W = W_2^2(\mu, \pi_{\text{QSD}})$ that satisfies:
1054: 
1055: $$
1056: \mathbb{E}[V_W(\Psi_{\text{kin}}(\mu))] \leq (1 - \kappa_{\text{kin}}\tau) V_W(\mu) + C_{\text{kin}}\tau^2
1057: 
1058: $$
1059: 
1060: where:
1061: - $\kappa_{\text{kin}} > 0$ is the hypocoercive contraction rate from the kinetic operator
1062: - $C_{\text{kin}}$ is the noise constant from BAOAB discretization
1063: - $\tau$ is the time step size
1064: 
1065: **Note:** The Foster-Lyapunov inequality bounds the **expected** Wasserstein distance after one application of the kinetic operator, averaged over the Langevin noise realizations.
1066: 
1067: **Step 3: Composition of Both Operators**
1068: 
1069: Applying both operators sequentially to a realization $\mu_t$, with the QSD $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ as the comparison measure (noting that $\Psi_{\text{total}}(\pi_{\text{QSD}}) = \pi_{\text{QSD}}$ by stationarity):
1070: 
1071: $$
1072: \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\mu_{t+1}, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] = \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\Psi_{\text{kin}}(\Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_t)), \pi_{\text{QSD}})]
1073: 
1074: $$
1075: 
1076: First apply cloning:
1077: 
1078: $$
1079: \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_t), \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq (1 - \kappa_W) W_2^2(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) + C_W
1080: 
1081: $$
1082: 
1083: Then apply kinetic:
1084: 
1085: $$
1086: \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\mu_{t+1}, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq (1 - \kappa_{\text{kin}}\tau) \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_t), \pi_{\text{QSD}})] + C_{\text{kin}}\tau^2
1087: 
1088: $$
1089: 
1090: Combining:
1091: 
1092: $$
1093: \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\mu_{t+1}, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq (1-\kappa_W)(1-\kappa_{\text{kin}}\tau) W_2^2(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) + (1-\kappa_{\text{kin}}\tau)C_W + C_{\text{kin}}\tau^2
1094: 
1095: $$
1096: 
1097: For small $\tau$, the product satisfies:
1098: 
1099: $$
1100: (1-\kappa_W)(1-\kappa_{\text{kin}}\tau) = 1 - \kappa_W - \kappa_{\text{kin}}\tau + O(\kappa_W \kappa_{\text{kin}} \tau) \leq 1 - \lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau
1101: 
1102: $$
1103: 
1104: where $\lambda_{\text{struct}} := \min(\kappa_W/\tau, \kappa_{\text{kin}})$ gives the dominant contraction rate.
1105: 
1106: Define the noise constant: $C_{\text{struct}} := C_W + C_{\text{kin}}\tau^2$.
1107: 
1108: **Step 4: From Wasserstein to Structural Variance**
1109: 
1110: The **variance decomposition** (Villani 2009, Theorem 7.17) states:
1111: 
1112: $$
1113: W_2^2(\mu, \pi) = W_2^2(\tilde{\mu}, \tilde{\pi}) + \|m_\mu - m_\pi\|^2
1114: 
1115: $$
1116: 
1117: where $\tilde{\mu}, \tilde{\pi}$ are centered versions and $m_\mu, m_\pi$ are the means.
1118: 
1119: Therefore, the structural variance (centered Wasserstein) satisfies:
1120: 
1121: $$
1122: V_{\text{struct}}(\mu, \pi) := W_2^2(\tilde{\mu}, \tilde{\pi}) = W_2^2(\mu, \pi) - \|m_\mu - m_\pi\|^2 \leq W_2^2(\mu, \pi)
1123: 
1124: $$
1125: 
1126: Applying this to our contraction result:
1127: 
1128: $$
1129: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_{t+1}, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq \mathbb{E}[W_2^2(\mu_{t+1}, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq (1 - \lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau) W_2^2(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) + C_{\text{struct}}
1130: 
1131: $$
1132: 
1133: Since $W_2^2(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) = V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) + \|m_{\mu_t} - m_{\pi}\|^2$ and the mean distance contracts as well ({prf:ref}`lem-mass-contraction-revival-death` for mass, standard Langevin contraction for position), we have:
1134: 
1135: $$
1136: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_{t+1}, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq (1 - \lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau) V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}}) + C_{\text{struct}}
1137: 
1138: $$
1139: 
1140: **Step 5: Exponential Convergence**
1141: 
1142: This is the standard Foster-Lyapunov drift inequality. Iterating and taking expectations:
1143: 
1144: $$
1145: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq (1-\lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau)^{t/\tau} \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_0, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] + \frac{C_{\text{struct}}}{\lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau}(1-(1-\lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau)^{t/\tau})
1146: 
1147: $$
1148: 
1149: Using $(1-\lambda_{\text{struct}}\tau)^{t/\tau} \approx e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t}$ for small $\tau$:
1150: 
1151: $$
1152: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_t, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] \leq e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t} \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{struct}}(\mu_0, \pi_{\text{QSD}})] + \frac{C_{\text{struct}}}{\lambda_{\text{struct}}}(1 - e^{-\lambda_{\text{struct}} t})
1153: 
1154: $$
1155:
